text: Detroit's skyscrapers shoot up on the horizon. Quicho’s t miles from Detroit, but it might as well be a hundred. Quicho's got it all: freezing weather, a closed down stee mill, and a diner that advertises a burnt cup of Maxwell House as "The World's Greatest Coffee." If Dr. Kevorkian took towns as patients, Quicho would be at the top of h list.

A police truck stops in front of the bank. Chief MARTY WA hops out of the truck and walks over to the bank. Checks make sure that the doors are locked. Marty's in his mid 30's. He'd be a good-looking guy if he followed through on his perennial New Year resolutions to switch to light beer and eat less red meat. He walks across the street to the Post Office. Checks the doors. Locked up tight. Marty climbs back into his truck. Si
Marty walks up to the front door. The store's closed. He pulls out a large key-ring, shuffles through the keys. Finds the one he wants. Opens up the store. Walks in.

Marty walks through the dark store. He grabs a six-pack o Bud out of a cooler. Walks over to the cash register. Doe a double-take at the porn magazines. Picks up a "Playboy. Flips through the pages for a quick beat.
(off centerfold) Nineteen eighty-one? Jesus, I'm getting old. Marty tosses it back on the rack. Then he throws a $5 bil and a note that reads, "6er of Bud -- Marty" on the cash register.

The station is small. It's made up of a large bullpen are Quicho's single jail cell, and Marty's office, which look out on the bullpen. Marty lays on the cot in the cell, watching "Sportscenter TV as he sips a Bud.
phene rings. Marty pulls himself up, reaches between bars and answers it.
Chief Walsh.
Chief, it's Ann Harrison. Somebody broke into my house.
I'll be right over.

Marty walks up the walkway to a small house. Before he ge there, the door opens. ANN HARRISON stands in the doorway wearing just an oversized t-shirt. Ann is beautiful -- especially by Quicho's standards. She Marty's age, but even if he kept up his New Years's resolutions she'd probably be out of his league. If Ann's face couldn't launch a thousand ships, it could get at le a couple hundred out of the harbor. Marty takes a long, less than professional, look at Ann a walks into the house.
A modest house. A lot of things are still boxed up. Can't tell whether Ann is moving in or moving out.
Did you get a look at him, Ann?
Yeah. He's about your height, your weight. Come to think of it, he kinda looked like you.
So he was good looking.
No. : Marty stares at her for a beat. She stares right back. A smile escapes from her full lips.
Sorry. Just not my type.
(under his breath) Well, bony dyed blondes aren't my type.  What?
{out loud) So -- this ugly man -- do you know how he got in the house?
The bedroom window. Marty follows her into the bedroom.
Marty checks the windows. They're all locked now.
Why don't you tell me what happened? .
Okay... Ann jumps in bed, pretends to be asleep.
I was asleep. But then I woke up, 'cause I felt the cold. I saw the window was open. Then I saw him. He was standing right where you are.
Right here? (she nods) Then what'd he do?
He came toward me... Marty comes closer to her.
Like this?
Uh-huh. Then he grabbed me. Marty grabs her arms. Pins her to the bed.
Like this?
But he was much stronger than you. (beat) Then he forced himself on top of me.
Like this?
(nods) Uh-huh. And his breath reeked. Kinda like yours.
Then what happened? — ANN He kissed me. Marty kisses her.
Then he stripped me naked. Marty starts to pull Ann's shirt over her head as he continues to kiss her. Ann starts to moan.
I'm sorry, I was confused. He ripped my shirt off. Marty rips her shirt down the middle, exposing her breast He licks at her breasts, teasing them with his tongue. An moans in pleasure.
You didn't put up much of a fight.

Oh, really? Ann flips Marty over so that she's on top of him. She fumbles with his belt, kicks his pants off of him. She ri open his shirt -- the buttons fly off. In seconds, they'r both naked. Ann straddles Marty.... grinds her hips into him... She arches her back, pushes her breasts into his face... He p her closer to him... Pushes deeper inside of her... The bed starts to shake. The springs squeak. Sweat begins to pour off of them as they claw at each other.  ut They groan leuder, both racing toward climax. As they mov together in perfect rhythm we...
Marty and Ann lay in bed, both spent and wearing expressi of contentment.
Did I tell you how glad I am that you moved back here?
Well, that makes one of us.
Come on, Quicho's not that bad. She gives him a look as if to say, "who you kidding?"
(laughs) Alright, it's awful. But it's a lot better with you here. Marty's cell phone rings. He starts to get out of bed, bu is jerked back -- his right hand is handcuffed to the headboard.
Can you get that, babe? Ann hops out of the bed and looks around Marty's discarde clothes until she finds the cell phone. She tosses it to Marty.
Chief Walsh. Marty listens for a long beat.
I'm on my way. Marty hangs up the phone.
(to Ann) Jay Guiney just tore up the Crowbar again. I gotta put him in the tank.
I don't think you're going anywhere.  Oy She smiles and holds up the keys to the handcuffs.
Marty, in his button-less police shirt, walks down the street, waving and talking to people. e stops ata newspaper machine. Puts his quarter and grabs a paper.

Marty is parked along a country highway, a radar gun stic out his window. Marty is reading the newspaper that he bought. The lead story reads: "Sarcetti Found Guilty." A picture of Marty testifying in court is tucked under the headline. A Ford Escort whips past Marty. The gun reads 70 MPH. Mar starts up the truck, hits the sirens. Pulls out after the Escort. The Escort pulls over. Marty stops his truck. Jumps out.
Marty walks up to the Escort. The DRIVER flashes a cocky smile at Marty. It's clear that there is no love lost between these two.
Problem, Chief?

You were speeding. The driver is CHRIS HARRISON, Quicho's 1985 Homecoming Ki Chris is built like a brick shit-house, still waiting for that day when they let 35 year old has-beens suit up for their high school football team.
C'mon. You're not gonna write me a ticket for that.

Chris, see, since you left town, things have changed a little. We actually made a new law -- now speed limits apply to former high school quarterbacks as well as everybody else. The unseen passenger laughs. And we recognize that laugh. it's Ann. But instead of Marty flipping out at seeing his lover in another man's car, Marty barely even looks at An
C'mon, we're late for Ann's doctor's appointment.
(real concern) Everything all right?
(leans forward) I'm fine, Marty. Chris pats Ann’s knee. Ann moves her leg so that Chris’ h falls off. Marty rips up the ticket.
I'm gonna let you off with a warning. Consider it your welcome home present, Chris.
(under his breath) Fuck you. MARTY — What?
I said, "thanks."
You should put your seatbelt on, Ann. (beat) Chris, you can keep yours off.

(smiles) Thanks. Marty tips his hat and walks back toward his car. As Mart walks back to his truck, he lowers his mask. It kills him that Ann is married to Chris. In the b.g. Chris peels back onto the highway. By the tim he's out of sight, he's going faster than when Marty pull him over.
Marty pulls up. A beat-up Mazda RX-7 is parked in Marty's clearly marked parking spot. Marty turns into another spa but makes sure that he leaves a nice dent on the Mazda's bumper.  eo

Hey, T. Chae here?

(nods) Bathroom. Dr. CHAE YI walks out of the bathroom, a newspaper tucked under his arm. He's the county coroner and Marty's best friend. - Chae is an Asian man who could be anywhere from 30 to 60. His steady diet of nicotine and alcohol have virtually guaranteed that he'll be on the receiving end of an autop in the next couple of years. He walks over to Marty, wipes his wet hands on Marty's sh
You need paper towels.
(gestures to parking lot) Maybe I'll buy ‘em with the money I get from your parking ticket. Marty walks into his office, Chae on his heels. Chae holds up the newspaper with Marty's picture on it.
I thought the camera only added ten pounds.
I was wondering how long it was going to take you to bring that up.
Maybe now is a good time to revisit my offer to invest the money --~-
"Investing?" I always thought it was called "misappropriation of funds."  w
Seven hundred grand in a stock fund, figure ten percent return over a year. Dean could set it up.
You mean Dean could launder it.
You say "to-mato", I say "tom-ato."
(deadpan) Let's call the whole thing off.

(laughing) You two still going to Costa Rica to open that fishing business?
(taps his watch) T, it's almost two-thirty. Tony nods glumly as he grabs a crossing guard sash anda handheld stop sign off the wall. He checks his gun to mak sure it's loaded.
Make sure you shoot to kill out there. Tony leaves.
I spoke to my buddy who runs the charter business there--

"Buddy?" You met him in a chat room. Marty goes to a wall-size safe. Marty dials the combo, th unlocks it with a key. He opens the safe, walks in. Chae follows behind him. The safe is the evidence locker.

The evidence locker is sparsely filled with a collection guns, knives, and other odd pieces of evidence. But Chae not interested in any of that. He is looking at a large evidence bag of $100 bills. The bag is marked, "Sarcetti case - No. 23432."
You know it's very tough to extradite from Costa Rica. Marty ignores him, puts the radar gun on a shelf.
What the hell they gonna do with the money anyway? Print up some "Just Say No" bumper stickers.
f£ they do, I'll make sure you get a whole bunch. Marty pushes Chae out of the evidence safe. Locks it.
(defeated) Ten years we've been talking about this. About getting out of here. Chae's cell phone rings. He answers it, listens for a bea then hangs up.
Shit. What kind of prick dies this late on a Friday afternoon before a three day weekend?
The nerve of some people. Chae walks out of the station. Marty sits down at his des Chae walks back in.
Hey. Marty looks up to see Chae giving him the finger.
Thanks for the dent, asshole.
Marty sits on a tired couch, talking on the phone and loo at his Palm VII.
Hey, T. It's me. How's everything at the office?
Uh, good, good.

Great, great. Then I just have one question for you? Why the hell are you at the god damn diner! MARTY!'S PALM: The GPS (Global Positioning System) module activated. He's looking at a map of Quicho. Tony is represented by a blinking blip on the screen.
Shit! Knock-knock. Marty looks up. Ann walks in.
Get your ass back there, T. Marty hangs up, then walks over to Ann. She looks trouble
You okay?
Can you take a ride with me?
Marty and Ann drive into Detroit. The skyscrapers tower around them. They drive in silence. Marty starts to say something, but stops himself. They pull into a hospital parking lot.
(nervous) Annie. What's going on?
Marty and Ann walk toward the hospital.
Can you walk a little behind me? This is Chris's hospital.
He's working now?
No, I'm just worried about his friends. Ann walks into the hospital. Marty waits a beat and then follows.
Ann talks to a nurse. Marty hangs back. He noticés a sig above the nurses' station: Oncology Department.
(under his breath) Shit. Ann comes back out. Marty follows Ann downstairs.
It's almost empty. Ann and Marty walk into...

A small, cramped office. Furniture and files are scattere everywhere. ivy League diplomas dominate the walls. DR. FRIELAND looks up when they enter the room. Frieland is i his mid 30s. And he seems very nervous. He plays with a bronze letter opener, turning it in his fingers.
Ann.
Hi, Bob. They hug.
(re: office) Who'd you piss off?
(forces a laugh) They've got me down here in the dungeon while they fix up my office.
{re: Marty) This is my brother Marty. Marty and Dr. Frieland shake hands.
Bob Frieland. (gestures to seats) Please. Ann and Marty sit down. Frieland pulls a file off his des studies it. Starts to say something and then stops. Goes back to the file.
Ann. I'm afraid, well, ah... there's been a bit of a setback...  Marty looks at Ann. But she doesn't meet his eyes. She steels herself. Whatever Frieland is about to say, she's been expecting it.
So this visit isn't just to pad your bill?

(weak smile) I'm, uh, afraid not. (beat / refers to charts) The cancer's not in remission. In fact, it's come back very aggressively. It's attacked your liver and lungs... Marty looks worse than Ann. He's devastated. Watching as his world comes crashing down.
How long?
Well, that's difficult--
Come on, Bob. What'd we agree to when I first came to you?
(smiles) No bullshit.
So... A long, tortured beat of silence. Dr. Frieland spins the letter opener in his fingers.
(pains him) Six months... Ann shakes her head, refuses to believe it.
But I feel fine--
And you will... for a little while longer. Ann reaches out, grabs Marty's hand.
(trying to smile} Next time, give me the bullshit, Doc. Frieland goes over to her, puts a hand on her arm.

Ann, there's a counselor here at the hospital I'd like you to see. She's, uh, she's... very good. But Ann's no longer listening. She stares out the window. Marty tries to console her, but she doesn't respond. After a beat, Ann stands up, extends her hand to Dr. Frie
Thanks for staying so late to see me, Bob.
Ann... This is not--
I appreciate everything you've done for me. I really do. {turns to Marty) Can we go now?
Ann, please--
(to Marty) I'd like to go.
Wait a second. Ann turns and leaves. Marty turns to Frieland.
There's gotta be something-- Frieland shakes his head slowly -- this is the toughest p of his job.
What about different doctors?
She's been to New York, to the Mayo Clinic--  us
What about experimental treatments? You know, that stuff you see on "60 Minutes?"... A long beat.
(shakes his head) I'm so sorry. Marty stands there, absorbing it. He drops his chin to hi chest, takes a deep breath. Dr. Frieland puts his arm on Marty's shoulder.
Thanks, Doctor. Marty stumbles out of the door.
Ann leans against her car. Her tough facade has crumbled. She's bawling. Marty runs up to her. He's crying, too. He buries her head in his chest as she cries even louder.
(after a beat) I locked the keys in the car. After a beat, they both start laughing their tears.
Marty drives in silence. Ann stares out the window. Marty keeps stealing glances at her. His heart is breaking. She catches him looking at her. She takes his hand.
Why didn't you tell me, Annie?

Because when I was with you, I forgot about it. For a couple of hours, I didn't think about dying. I just, I... You made me feel good. She squeezes his hand. They pass a sign that reads, "Entering Quicho."
This why you came back?
No. We came back because we lost our house.  ov
Chris's gambling?
(nods) And since I couldn't sell my mom's house, I figured we might as well live in it. So, I was born in this shitty town and now I'm gonna die in this shitty town.

We'll go to other doctors--
(laughs) I've been to ten doctors in three states, Marty. And the only thing that changes is the magazines in the waiting rooms. She stares out the window. He reaches over and grabs her hand.
They lie in bed, both lost in their own thoughts. After a beat, Marty leans over and kisses Ann's forehead. Pulls h closer to him. She kisses his chest.
Let's leave.

And go where?
Wherever you want. The Caribbean, Europe... Ann kisses him softly. She's touched by the gesture, but knows that it's not realistic.
Should we take your millions or mine?
We'll figure out the money.
Well, it won't take us long to figure it out since your ex-wife gets most of your money and Chris bet all ours on losing football teams. Ann pulls his face to hers. Kisses him.
(beat) Marty, I can't leave with you. I mean, this, this is great, but it's not real.
Not real? Ann, I've been in love with you since we were in first grade.
(smiles) Mrs. Green's class, right? Ann pulls herself up in bed, clutching the sheet to her. grabs her panties and pulls them on. Stands up and starts get dressed.

It wasn't right for me to drag you into this. Marty swings out of bed, grabs her arms.  o

Marty, I'm dying...
I don't care if you have six months or six minutes left. I just wanna be there for all of them. She gently takes his hands off her arm. Kisses him. Looks into his eyes.
You know when you take off a band- aid.

I'm the one wearing the band-aid. She turns, heads for the door. Fights every urge to turn back to him. By the time she reaches the door, the tears have already started falling. Marty watches as she disappears out the door. Continues stare even after he hears her car start.
